title: projects/benchmarks/span-labeling-datasets at v3 · explosion/projects

last_post.content:
Happy to announce the release of spaCy 3.5.1!

It introduces 'spancat_singlelabel', support for mypy v1.0, new operators for the dependency matchers, a 'PlainTextCorpusReader', various bug fixes and more!

We recently also added two new resources:

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/span-labeling-datasets bundles various NER & spancat datasets + .spacy convertors

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/ner_embeddings contains all resources to reproduce the results of our "Multi hash embeddings" technical report: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09255

Happy weekend!

title: GitHub - grvsmth/jest_test at ecmascript_modules

last_post.content:
Some years ago I created a small repo to demonstrate using #JestJS to create unit tests for #javascript. Today I'm releasing a new branch to demonstrate how to implement Jest's new native support for ECMAScript modules!

The key steps are:
1. Import jest explicitly
2. Use jest.unstable_mockModule()
3. Inside the `describe` function, use a dynamic import, e.g. `const utilModule = import("../util.js")`
4. Inside the `test` function, extract the class/method
5. Mock away!

https://github.com/grvsmth/jest_test/tree/ecmascript_modules

title: BUG: inconsistency between prepared and unprepared polygon contains predicate · Issue #740 · libgeos/geos

last_post.content:
GEOS is pretty darn robust, but there's an interesting class of failures that are the root of more than one of the extant issues.

When evaluating predicates (true/false tests on geometry relationships) and full DE9IM relationships, JTS/GEOS will perform noding on the inputs before evaluating the relationship between them.

This results in a sort of "heisenberg uncertainty principle" of geometry predicates. The act of evaluating them changes them slightly.

https://github.com/libgeos/geos/issues/740#issuecomment-1325776721

last_post.content:
I did some more work on my JavaScript Fedi client over the weekend:

https://github.com/FahimF/FediJS

I’m not progressing as fast as I had done with other Masto/Fedi clients in the past in terms of adding features, and yet, it’s so much easier (at least so far) to add new features for the JavaScript client 🙂

Now, I’m by no means a JavaScript guru. Sure, I’ve been using JavaScript since the early days of the web, but only as needed. It has never been one of my main programming languages. So I find it interesting that I can do a lot more with a lot less code in this particular instance.

I’m thinking of adding hashtag and lists support next weekend possibly. I guess we’ll see how it goes …

* Set LinkingTo: deft
* Set Depends: deft
* #include <deft.h>

And how to write a correct deft.h and exporting of C callables from {deft}'s init.c
